question: Suppose f and g produce only positive outputs and f(n) ≪ g(n). Will g(n) be O(f(n))?
explanation: No. f(n) ≪ g(n) means f grows strictly slower than g. Big-O acts as a ≤ operator, so asking if g(n) is O(f(n)) is asking if g grows slower or equal to f. Since g is strictly faster, it cannot be bounded asymptotically by f.

question: Dividing a problem of size n into k subproblems, each of size n/m, has the best big-Θ running time when...
explanation: By the Master Theorem, if a (subproblems k) < b (reduction factor m), the work at the root dominates, heavily limiting the exponential blowup at the leaves. Thus, minimizing k relative to m gives the best run times.

question: What is the Big-Theta of the recurrence T(n) = 2T(n/2) + n?
explanation: Merge sort recurrence. Both a=2 and b=2, so log_b(a) = log_2(2) = 1. Since work per level is c*n^1, we are in the balanced case of the Master Theorem. Thus, Θ(n log n).

question: Suppose f(x) is O(h(x)) and g(x) is O(h(x)). Must f(x)g(x) be O(h(x))?
explanation: No. Let f(x) = x, g(x) = x, and h(x) = x. Both f(x) and g(x) are O(x). However, f(x)g(x) = x^2, which is NOT O(x). Multiplication requires adding the exponents of the bounds, not just keeping the same bound.
